column1: Seabrook is a city in Harris County in the U.S. state of Texas
column2: with some water surface area located within Chambers County.  The population was 11
column3: 952 at the 2010 census. Several fish markets line the city's waterfront
column4: while antique shops and bed and breakfast establishments are found in the city's downtown area. The city is home to several miles of trails
column5: which connect multiple city parks to each other.

column1: Seabrook is known for its fish markets on Waterfront Drive where resident shrimpers and fishermen bring in their catches daily. Besides bordering the bay
column2: the city encompasses marshes through which runoff from inland fields drain to the bay. The piece of land was purchased by Seabrook W. Sydnor
column3: who was the son of a Galveston slave trader
column4: John Seabrook Sydnor in 1895. In March 1903
column5: the Seabrook Company of Houston created a layout of the proposed Seabrook Town site. The new town attracted fishermen
column6: merchants and even a few residents.

column1: The Galveston Hurricane of 1900 demolished the local school
column2: but by 1905 it was restored and was run by three teachers who taught 100 students. The local schools became part of the Clear Creek Independent School District in 1947. The population of Seabrook rose from 200 to 560 before the Great Depression
column3: but fell to 200 in 1936
column5: when the Albert and Ernest Fay shipyard opened. It could handle 150 boats
column6: and opened up jobs and is the main cause of the population increase. Despite damage from Hurricane Carla
column7: a bridge linking Seabrook and Kemah was completed in 1961. With the opening of the bridge and the Johnson Space Center (JSC) in Houston

column2: the decision was made to start the construction of a fixed-span bridge that was tall enough for sailboats to pass under. After this bridge was finished
column3: Highway 146 was linked all the way from Galveston to Texas State Highway 225. This spurred a further increase in the population of Seabrook to its present level of nearly 12
column4: 000 people. Seabrook's residents are quite diversified and are employed in a variety of professional positions. Quite a few residents have ties to the chemical and oil industry as well as the NASA space program.

column1: Seabrook is located on Galveston Bay at Clear Lake
column2: southeast of Houston near Pasadena and La Porte. According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 21.3 square miles (55.1 km2)
column4: of which 5.3 square miles (13.8 km2) is land and 15.9 square miles (41.3 km2)

column1: Seabrook has an oceanic humid subtropical climate
column2: with consistent rainfall throughout the year
column3: but usually with heavier amounts during the hot and humid summer months.

column1: A historic downtown area was constructed in the early 20th century and it stands today
column2: with many locals running their businesses. Most are antique shops or bed and breakfast places.

column1: Seabrook is host to the Texas Concours d'Elegance "Keels & Wheels" classic car and boat show held each year the first weekend in May at Lakewood Yacht Club. The Seabrook Festival of the Arts is held annually on the grounds of Seabrook City Hall and Community House at First Street
column2: where artists exhibit paintings
column3: sculpture
column7: photography and musical performances by Texas musicians. The festival is sponsored by the City of Seabrook in cooperation with the Art Consortium of the Texas Gulf Coast.

column1: The goal of the Pelican Path Project has been to improve Seabrook's identity as a community and one of the largest migratory paths in North America
column2: and a bird sanctuary  to both the brown and white pelicans. The project also displays connectedness of the city by its many bed and breakfasts
column3: close family values
column4: available water attractions and its unique downtown of small businesses.

column1: Most businesses in Seabrook have purchased a pelican from Pelican Project and have customized it to represent their type of business
column2: as well as the city of Seabrook. This project has not only attracted tourism to Seabrook
column3: but united the businesses of the city.  Artists from all over Texas have participated in this project
column4: which has attracted future plans for more cultural art projects in Seabrook.

column1: There are 8 miles (13 km) of continuous trails from Hammer Street to Galveston Bay at Pine Gully Park
column2: where the Lucky Trails Marathon is run in March. The trail system was built from crushed granite
column3: which connects most of the city's parks
column4: including Robinson and Pine Gully Parks. The trail system traverses habitats for a wide variety of wildlife.

column1: In addition to the city being designated as a bird sanctuary
column2: the city includes four sites on the Great Texas Coastal Birding Trail. The only other site in the Clear Lake area on this Texas trail is the Armand Bayou Nature Center.

column1: Pupils in Seabrook attend schools in Clear Creek Independent School District. The community is within the Board of Trustees District 1
column2: represented by Robert Allan Davee as of 2008.Most Seabrook residents are zoned to James F. Bay Elementary School
column3: which was originally known as Seabrook Elementary but was renamed in 1969 to honor the principal who had served for many years. Some residents are zoned to Ed White Elementary School in El Lago
column4: which was built in 1965 and was named after Ed White
column5: the famous astronaut who died in the fire working on the Apollo mission.

column1: All Seabrook residents are zoned to Seabrook Intermediate School (Seabrook). Seabrook Intermediate also houses the Science Magnet Program
column2: which offers an enriched Science curriculum with many outside science activities. This program is an application-process program and the students accepted are gifted in the field of science. Seabrook Intermediate also houses the Living Materials Center
column3: which is the home for over 60 species of animals. The Living Materials Center is available to all students in the school and throughout the district.All Seabrook residents are zoned to Clear Falls High School in League City. Residents were previously zoned to Clear Lake High School in Clear Lake City

column1: The Harris County Public Library Evelyn Meador Branch serves the community. The library opened on June 26
column2: 1988. The original planning of the library started in 1985 when five Seabrook residents met Harris County Commissioner Jim Fonteno. The library suffered enough damage from Hurricane Ike that it was completely rebuilt.  The new
column3: larger library reopened on June 28

column1: Harris County Transit previously operated public transportation in Seabrook. The Seabrook Post Office is located at 1600 Second Street.

The Seabrook Volunteer Fire Department (SVFD) provides fire protection and medical first responder services to the city. The FD operates out of two stations and also has a fire boat docked at a local boat marina. SVFD is staffed entirely by volunteer firefighters. Equipment operated by SVFD includes:

column1: The city of Seabrook was under mandatory evacuation for Hurricane Ike on the morning of September 13
column2: 2008. Hurricane Ike was the 3rd most destructive hurricane to hit the United States. In Seabrook
column3: the storm surge not only knocked out the streets as a means of transportation
column4: but also knocked the power out for the entire city
column5: along with many others. Because Seabrook is surrounded by water
column6: the aftermath of debris and boats on the roads was phenomenal from all of the boat docks close to shore.  Seabrook residents were left without power and running water for up to a month after Hurricane Ike made landfall.A month after the hurricane
column7: Seabrook was still dealing with people not being able to live in the conditions
column8: even after the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) came. The students zoned to schools in the Clear Creek Independent School District (which are all the residents in Seabrook) missed almost three weeks of school due to the evacuation and the damage to buildings and roads in the Seabrook and surrounding areas.
